subject: Re: The Software Inferno - Convincing management of the benefits of unit tests
msgSnippet: ... sure ... a ... requirements, They need to test that their unit meets the requirement. ... Indeed. ... No. I think this fits in the iterative approach. ...
messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, David Saff <saff@...> wrote:
>
> Jan,
>
> Thanks for being willing to say something controversial. Let me be
sure
> I'm understanding you. Are you saying one of these two things, or
a
> third thing entirely?
>
> 1) Teams need only test that the whole system meets client
requirements,

They need to test that their unit meets the requirement.

> not the behavior of any individual class.

Indeed.

> 2) Teams need only write all of their tests during a first-pass
> "requirements" phase, and not during development.

No. I think this fits in the iterative approach.


>
> Thanks,
>
> David
>

Regards, Jan

j_cumps wrote:
> <controversial>
>
> I'm still not convinced of the economics of unit testing at the
> lowest level.
> I've been lurking this list for quite some time, attended online
and
> offline seminars, listened to to Agile, XP and TDD talks, ...
>
> And apply it at work.
>
> I am convinced that TDD is a right approach.
> I see big value in the agile methods.
> But to my feeling unit testing can be done at the requirements
level.
>
> That's why I am thinking about testdriving this approach:
>
> 1: Write unit tests only to test the requirements.
> 2: Write the code that implements these requirements, until tests
> pass.
> 3: Run the unit tests together with a code coverage tool
> 4: delete all executable lines of code not covered by the unit test
>
> </controversial>
>
> Regards, Jan
